Friday brought a dramatic Presidential executive order on immigration. In essence, it’s a ban directed at Muslims - a clear violation of Constitutional protections against religious discrimination that rolls back our Nation’s long, hard fought battle for greater inclusion. In a nutshell, President Trump suspended entry of all refugees into the U.S. for four months, stopped Syrian refugees from entering the U.S. indefinitely, and banned citizens from seven predominately Muslim nations from coming to America for 90 days. These steps are both radical and unnecessary. To be clear, under new legislation passed with my support during the last session of Congress, we already have the toughest, most comprehensive refugee vetting process of any nation in the world. Before entering this country, refugees undergo 18 to 24 months of investigations by multiple U.S. intelligence agencies. It’s as good a process as is humanly possible to implement. That said, if there are things that need fixing, we should do it through comprehensive and bipartisan immigration reform – something Republican leaders have consistently refused to allow.

Today, on #WorldMentalHealthDay, I want to take a moment to speak out in support of those and their families who have struggled with this issue.  #MentalHealth is no different than any other health problem - it needs to be recognized, diagnosed, and treated. But because of stigma, slow access to care, and a lack of treatment center beds, patients often don't get the timely help that they need.  That's why last Congress, I cosponsored the Helping Families in Mental Health Crisis Act, a bipartisan bill that passed the House of Representatives. We've got to fight mental illness the way we fight cancer and heart disease -- with funding, with legislation, and most of all, for unwavering love and support for those affected.   Together, we can end mental illness stigma, and ensure that every person in America has full access to the resources and treatment that they need.

Today, I joined 188 of my colleagues in urging the Administration to rescind its final rules on #BirthControl – which could leave women across Minnesota and the United States without health care coverage for contraception.    The fact of the matter is, birth control is health care. It helps improve women’s and children’s health, it reduces the risk of unintended pregnancy, and it empowers women and their families to make decisions about when to start and grow a family.   Despite all the benefits of birth control, the Administration’s final rules create “exemptions” that virtually any employer, insurance company, or school can use to deny women birth control coverage. In other words, employers and insurance companies have effective “veto power” in deciding whether or not they’re going to provide this coverage.    This is plain wrong. Women should not be singled out by rules that force them to pay more for common health care services.    And what’s more: These rules take effect immediately, even though there was NO open and transparent process where all key stakeholders were allowed to comment.    That’s why I’m demanding these rules be rescinded. The Administration must recognize the discriminatory nature of these rules, and engage in a normal process where they listen to women and health care professionals before changing laws.

I am proud to join Congressman John Conyers, Jr. and Senator Edward J. Markey on a bill to ensure that President Donald Trump cannot launch a first strike against North Korea without the approval of Congress.   The lives of billions of innocent people, and the future of the world as we know it, is at stake. Should President Trump launch a first strike against North Korea, it could easily escalate into a nuclear war with catastrophic consequences. A preemptive strike would also incentivize North Korea to attack the 23,468 U.S. military troops currently stationed in South Korea.    That’s why I’ve joined numerous colleagues in introducing legislation to stop President Trump from disregarding the Constitution and launching a first strike attack on North Korea without Congressional approval.   It’s important to note that this legislation does not stop the United States from responding and launching an attack if North Korea attacks the U.S. or its allies first.   The bill’s purpose is simply to put safeguards on a process that gives the President single-handed control to launch a first attack – even a nuclear attack – without a Congressional declaration of war, as the Constitution requires.  As always, diplomacy, not war, is our best chance and our strongest tool in dealing with nations like North Korea. I will continue to advocate for a diplomatic process to protect the lives of innocent people and the future of our world.  http://www.newsweek.com/us-preemptive-strike-north-korea-would-kill-millions-and-risk-unacceptable-war-693466

The cruel and inhumane animal fighting industry has no place in any jurisdiction in the United States. That’s why I’m introducing a new bill, the Parity in Animal Cruelty Enforcement Act, to ensure that there is no refuge for animal fighters anywhere in the United States.  Right now, legal loopholes exist that leave doubt as to whether federal anti-animal fighting laws apply in Puerto Rico and other U.S. territories. As a result, “safe havens” can still exist where animal fighting operations are allowed to operate and profit from the terrible pain and suffering.   During fights, the animals are often drugged and forced to keep fighting even after they’ve suffered grievous injuries such as broken bones, deep gashes, punctured lungs and pierced eyes. In cockfighting, birds have metal weapons attached to their legs and typically suffer slow painful deaths.  Animal fighting is damaging to human communities, too. In places where animal fighting is present, associated crimes such as illegal drug dealing, gambling and violence follow in its wake.   As a society, we have an obligation to protect those without a voice, including animals who are cruelly forced to fight one another. By closing the loopholes and explicitly banning animal fighting, we can protect innocent animals, improve life for communities, and end this shameful practice once and for all.  http://www.humanesociety.org/news/press_releases/2017/10/federal-legislation.html?referrer=https://www.google.com/

“The legend lives on from the Chippewa on down Of the big lake they call Gitche Gumee The lake, it is said, never gives up her dead When the skies of November turn gloomy.”   --Gordon Lightfoot, “The Wreck of the Edmund Fitzgerald.”   Forty-two years ago today, the SS Edmund Fitzgerald, a Great Lakes freighter, sank during a vicious Lake Superior storm. It is the most famous shipwreck in Great Lakes history, taking the lives of its entire crew of 29 men.   The SS Edmund Fitzgerald’s  main job was hauling iron ore from the mines on the shores of Minnesota to the steel mills in Ohio and Michigan. At the time, “The Fitz” was the largest ship ever to travel across the Great Lakes, and remains the largest to have ever sunk there. The ship was known by many other names, including “The Queen of the Great Lakes,” and later, tragically, “Titanic of the Great Lakes.”   On November 10th, 1975, the Edmund Fitzgerald SS was heading to Whitefish Point when a storm began brewing. By night, the swells reached 35 feet and the wind speeds surged to nearly 100 mph. A radio message was sent from the ship at 7:10 pm, assuring another boat that “We are holding our own.” It was the last message ever sent from the ship.   Later, rescue boats searched the area, but found only a pair of lifeboats and debris. The Edmund Fitzgerald had sunk, taking the lives of all 29 crew members, most of whom were from Minnesota, Wisconsin, Michigan, and Ohio.   Each year on November 10th, the ship’s bell – which was recovered by divers – tolls 29 times for each member of the Edmund Fitzgerald crew, and a 30th time for the nearly 30,000 mariners who have lost their lives on the Great Lakes.  https://m.youtube.com/watch?v=9vST6hVRj2A

Last night, the House passed --  with overwhelming bipartisan support -- my bill, H.R. 3115, the Superior National Forest Land Exchange Act, which finalizes a long-awaited land exchange in Northern Minnesota between the U.S. Forest Service and PolyMet Mining.   I’d like to make a few things very clear about this bill.   First, it does NOT involve the Boundary Waters Canoe Area Wilderness in any way. I love the Boundary Waters, and I’ve spent wonderful times there with my family. In fact, I was one of the ORIGINAL COSPONSORS of the legislation that established the Boundary Waters as a protected area! I have never and will never support mining in the Boundary Waters, or any mining project that fails to meet our strict environmental protection standards.  Furthermore, the land exchange area is actually south of the Laurentian continental divide – meaning that water from that area PHYSICALLY CANNOT flow north into the BWCA. It’s geologically impossible.   Second, this bill does NOT APPROVE any mining project. Any proposed project would still have to go through the rigorous federal and state approval process in order to move forward. And if it can’t meet those standards, it doesn’t move forward.  Third, this legislation is a GOOD DEAL all around. It helps create good paying jobs on the Iron Range, and it opens up 2,000 acres of wetlands, lakeshore, and wild rice waters to the public. And it’s supported by a bipartisan majority of the Minnesota Congressional Delegation, Minnesota Senators Amy Klobuchar and Al Franken, Democratic and Republican leaders in the Minnesota legislature, and communities, businesses, private citizens, and economic development organizations throughout the region.   I understand the concerns of environmentalists, especially when it comes to protecting the BWCA. I too am absolutely committed to protecting those sacred areas. But this is an instance in which the facts just don’t line up – because this legislation has no chance of harming the Boundary Waters. I would never put my name on it if that were the case.   The simple fact is, this bill is an all-around good deal for jobs, for the public, and for the environment. I am proud to have supported it and look forward to its progress in the Senate.
